channel.title: Science Talk
channel.description: Science Talk is a weekly science audio show covering the latest in the world of science and technology. Join Steve Mirsky each week as he explores cutting-edge breakthroughs and controversial issues with leading scientists and journalists. He is also an articles editor and columnist at Scientific American magazine and his column, "Antigravity", is one of science writing's rate venues for humor. Check our the new daily podcast from Scientific American: "60-Second Science." To view all of our archived podcasts please go to www.scientificamerican.com/podcast
channel.copyright: 2012 Scientific American, a division of Nature America, Inc. All Rights Reserved.
channel.itunes:subtitle: A weekly exploration of the latest developments in science and technology
channel.itunes:summary: Science Talk is a weekly science audio show covering the latest in the world of science and technology. Join Steve Mirsky each week as he explores cutting-edge breakthroughs and controversial issues with leading scientists and journalists. He is also an articles editor and columnist at Scientific American magazine and his column, "Antigravity", is one of science writing's rate venues for humor. Check our the new daily podcast from Scientific American: "60-Second Science." To view all of our archived podcasts please go to www.scientificamerican.com/podcast
channel.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: The Transit of Venus, Part 2
item.description: Mark Anderson, author of the book The Day The World Discovered the Sun, talks about the transit of Venus coming up on June 5th or 6th in different parts of the world and how it will be of use to astronomers searching for exoplanets
item.itunes:subtitle: The Transit of Venus, Part 2
item.itunes:summary: Mark Anderson, author of the book The Day The World Discovered the Sun, talks about the transit of Venus coming up on June 5th or 6th in different parts of the world and how it will be of use to astronomers searching for exoplanets
item.itunes:keywords: Mark Anderson, Venus transit, exoplanets
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: The Transit of Venus, Part 1
item.description: With a transit of Venus coming up on June 5th or 6th in different parts of the world, Mark Anderson, author of the book The Day The World Discovered the Sun, talks about the great efforts to track the transits of Venus in the 1760s and the science they would produce
item.itunes:subtitle: The Transit of Venus, Part 1
item.itunes:summary: With a transit of Venus coming up on June 5th or 6th in different parts of the world, Mark Anderson, author of the book The Day The World Discovered the Sun, talks about the great efforts to track the transits of Venus in the 1760s and the science they would produce
item.itunes:keywords: Mark Anderson, Venus transit, Halley, Captain Cook, Jean-Baptist Chappe
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Virus Victors: People Who Control HIV
item.description: Bruce Walker, professor of medicine at Harvard Medical School and director of the Ragon Institute of Massachusetts General Hospital, M.I.T. and Harvard, talks about his article in the July issue of Scientific American magazine called "Controlling HIV," about rare individuals who never develop AIDS after being infected by the virus
item.itunes:subtitle: Virus Victors: People Who Control HIV
item.itunes:summary: Bruce Walker, professor of medicine at Harvard Medical School and director of the Ragon Institute of Massachusetts General Hospital, M.I.T. and Harvard, talks about his article in the July issue of Scientific American magazine called "Controlling HIV," about rare individuals who never develop AIDS after being infected by the virus
item.itunes:keywords: Bruce Walker, HIV, elite HIV controllers
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: The Football Concussion Crisis, Part 1
item.description: NFL Hall of Famer Harry Carson joins former NBC anchor Stone Phillips and pathologist Bennet Omalu for a discussion of chronic traumatic encephalopathy among football players. Recorded May 12th at the Ensemblestudiotheatre.org, site of the new play Headstrong about the brain injury issue
item.itunes:subtitle: The Football Concussion Crisis, Part 1
item.itunes:summary: NFL Hall of Famer Harry Carson joins former NBC anchor Stone Phillips and pathologist Bennet Omalu for a discussion of chronic traumatic encephalopathy among football players. Recorded May 12th at the Ensemblestudiotheatre.org, site of the new play Headstrong about the brain injury issue
item.itunes:keywords: CTE, Harry Carson, Bennet Omalu, chronic traumatic encephalopathy, concussion
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Killer Chimps and Funny Feet: Report from the AAPA Conference
item.description: Scientific American editor Kate Wong talks about the recent conference of the American Association of Physical Anthropologists in Portland, Ore., where subjects included killer chimps, unprecedented fossil sharing among researchers and divergent hominid foot forms
item.itunes:subtitle: Killer Chimps and Funny Feet: Report from the AAPA Conference
item.itunes:summary: Scientific American editor Kate Wong talks about the recent conference of the American Association of Physical Anthropologists in Portland, Ore., where subjects included killer chimps, unprecedented fossil sharing among researchers and divergent hominid foot forms

item.title: Getting Guinea Worm Gone: Report from the AHCJ Conference
item.description: Scientific American editor Christine Gorman talks about the recent conference of the Association of Health Care Journalists, including Jimmy Carter's efforts against guinea worm and trachoma, and Rosalynn Carter's mental health initiatives
item.itunes:subtitle: Getting Guinea Worm Gone: Report from the AHCJ Conference

item.title: AAAS Report: Fracking, Whale Rights, Higgs Evidence and Twitter Truthiness
item.description: Scientific American editors Mark Fischetti and Michael Moyer discuss some of the sessions they attended at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. Subjects covered include fracking, cetacean rights, the Higgs boson and Twitter's truthiness
item.itunes:subtitle: AAAS Report: Fracking, Whale Rights, Higgs Evidence and Twitter Truthiness

item.title: If You're Happy, How You Know It
item.description: Social scientist Roly Russell, of the Sandhill Institute in British Columbia, talked with Scientific American's Mark Fischetti at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science about potentially better measures than GDP of a nation's well-being

item.title: More with Maryn: McKenna on Antibiotic Resistance

item.title: Fecal Transplants: The Straight Poop
item.description: Journalist and author Maryn McKenna talks about fecal transplants, which have proved to be exceptionally effective at restoring a healthy intestinal microbiome and curing C. diff infections, yet remain in regulatory limbo

item.title: The YouTube SpaceLab Competition
item.description: If you're 14 to 18 years old, you still have until December 14th to prepare a two-minute video of a suggestion for an experiment to be performed at the International Space Station and upload it to youtube.com/spacelab. Winners will see their experiment performed in space

item.title: Large Hadron Collider Backgrounder
item.description: Thomas LeCompte of Argonne National Lab was the physics coordinator for the ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider. He talks about the instrument and its future, as we await the December 13th announcement as to whether the LHC has found the Higgs particle

item.title: An Accelerating Universe: The 2011 Nobel Prize in Physics
item.description: Listen to the announcement of the 2011 Nobel Prize in Physics, to Saul Perlmutter, Brian Schmidt and Adam Reiss, from the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences. Following the formal announcement comes an explanation of the research, which tracked type Ia supernovae to discover that the expansion of the universe was accelerating. And a phone conversation with new Nobel laureate Brian Schmidt
item.itunes:subtitle: An Accelerating Universe: The 2011 Nobel Prize in Physics
item.itunes:summary: Listen to the announcement of the 2011 Nobel Prize in Physics, to Saul Perlmutter, Brian Schmidt and Adam Reiss, from the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences. Following the formal announcement comes an explanation of the research, which tracked type Ia supernovae to discover that the expansion of the universe was accelerating. And a phone conversation with new Nobel laureate Brian Schmidt
item.itunes:keywords: Saul Perlmutter, Brian Schmidt, Adam Reiss, accelerating universe, Nobel Prize, type 1a supernova
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Carl Zimmer on Evolution in the Big City

item.title: Nobel Laureate Avram Hershko: The Orchestra in the Cell
item.description: Nobel laureate Avram Hershko, who determined cellular mechanisms for breaking down proteins, talks about his research in a conversation recorded at the Lindau Nobel Laureate Meeting in Lindau, Germany. And Scientific American Editor in Chief Mariette DiChristina discusses the recent inaugural Google Science Fair

item.title: Nobel Laureate Peter Agre: From Aquaporins to Lutefisk
item.description: Peter Agre, 2003 Chemistry Nobel laureate for his work on aquaporins, the proteins that allow water into and out of cells, talks about his research, his upbringing and why he almost ran for the Senate, in a conversation recorded at the Lindau Nobel Laureate Meeting in Lindau, Germany

item.title: The Spewings of Titan (and More from the AGU Meeting)
item.description: Scientific American editor Davide Castelvecchi joins us from San Francisco to talk about some of the highlights of the meeting of the American Geophysical Union, including volcanoes on Titan, x-rays from lightning, the biota of the Sulawesi Sea, and the connection between light pollution and air pollution. Plus, we'll test your knowledge of some recent science in the news

item.title: Photograph 51: Rosalind Franklin and the Race For The Double Helix of DNA (Part 2 of 2)
item.description: Photograph 51 is a new play about Rosalind Franklin, Watson and Crick, and the race to determine the structure of DNA, at the Ensemble Studio Theatre in New York City, running through November 21st. A panel discussion about the play on November 2nd featured crystallography expert Helen Berman, biologist and Franklin scholar Lynne Osman Elkin, science journalist Nicholas Wade, playwright Anna Ziegler and moderator Stuart Firestein
item.itunes:subtitle: Photograph 51: Rosalind Franklin and the Race For The Double Helix of DNA (Part 2 of 2)
